title: Voice of the Mirror: They came in their thousands because they care so much about the NHS
text:
NHS march in London reaches Parliament Square Share this video Watch Next 
But it is too busy tearing itself apart – though John McDonnell ’s offer of a cuppa with ­arch-critic Peter Mandelson is an olive branch in the right direction. 
The choice then is whether to charge more tax, divert money from elsewhere or ask people to pay for some health services. 
The British are as sentimental about the NHS as they are about puppies and kittens, which have better access to healthcare than humans. 
Vets are open 24/7, and you do not see cats and dogs queueing around the block to get in. Nor do they end up on trolleys for 12 hours. 
But vets are paid for their services by their customers. Our sentimentality for the NHS means we cling to the principle of it being free at the point of use. Read More Hundreds of thousands of patients waiting a YEAR for life-changing surgery on NHS The NHS march in London (Photo: Alamy) 
Yet that was true for only the first three years of its existence. Charges for spectacles and dentures were introduced in 1951, and for eye tests in 1988. 
Many patients pay for prescriptions and for a visit to the dentist. 
Can it be right then that a billionaire can see a GP for free when each appointment costs taxpayers £45? 
As the population ages, social care must go hand in hand with health care. 
But Philip Hammond has been embarrassed into ­abandoning a death tax to pay for it. A protester with a sign (Photo: Getty) 
Can it be wrong for someone with an estate worth more than £325,000 to pay an extra 10 per cent on the remainder so that the elderly can be properly looked after? 
Or we could pay for the NHS by doing without something else – nuclear submarines, for instance. That would free up £40billion. 
Or we could find that £40billion by paying more tax. A 7p in the £ increase across all rates should do it. 
Seven out of 10 people in a Mirror poll said they were prepared to pay more if they knew the money would go to the NHS. Yet politicians also think that if they campaign for higher taxes they will not get elected. 
Perhaps they are reading us wrong. Perhaps the time for an NHS tax has come. 
One thing is certain. If we truly value our NHS, we are – one way or another – going to have to pay more for it. Like us on Facebook
